content:
Select and study another gonosome with planulae showing near
the tip. Squeeze or open the gonophore with needles and liberate
the planulae. Notice their ciliated ectoderm and watch their move-
ments.   
Select some gonosomes with very well matured planulae. The
latter should be two or three times longer than broad, and show
maggot~like movements inside the gonangium. Liberate such planulae
with needles and place them in watch glasses with sea water (not
more than 2 or 5 specimens to a watch glass). Qover them and set
aside for future examination.
The planulae should attach to the glass in 4 to 10 hours. Each
should open a mouth, had out tentacles, secrete hydrotheca and
perisarc and become a fully fonned individual polyp in two or three
days.
When the planulae have attached, the sea water should be
changed at least twice a day. From time to time as laboratory work
permits, study the stages of development that unfold from the
planula.
Male gonosomes are similar in form.to the female. The gono~
phores when mature shed sperm, which become active upon coming in
contact with the sea water.
Qydractinia. (June, July)

he unusual colonies of this form are found growing on hermit
crabs or under rocks. They include nutritive individuals (ordinary
polyps), long filiform defensive individuals with apical knobs of
and gonosomes. These three types of individuals arise
from an enerusting hydrorhiza anastomosis whiah is covered with a
rust-red crust and often studded with spines.
The gonosomes are usually without tentacles and have a large
knob of on the proboscis; each bears a number of gono-
phores which are medusa-buds reduced to the status of sporosacs.
Male and female colonies can be told apart if ripe, since the eggs
within the sporesacs are dull green against the red hydrorhiza,
and the sperm when.mature are white,
Hydractinia is handiest for study when growing on Littorina
shells inhabited by the small hermit crab Pagurus. Select a shell
bearing a ripe male colony and one bearing a ripe female colony,
and put that together in a fingerbowl of sea water. After 48 hours
look for developing eggs, embryos and swimming and attached planulae
in the dish. Isolate some in watch glasses of sea water for study
of the further development. (Beckwith lQld).
Eggs are heavily yolky and green, and the cleavage is quite
irregular, there being frequent ameboid changes in shape. Gastru~
lation starts at the l6-cell stage by mixed delamination and multi-
polar proliferation.
